ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a lot about the development of important ideas during the Age of Revolutions.
I gained a better understanding of the development of ideology in the wake of the French Revolution
Read all the major authors from the Revolutionary period with interesting and active discussion including critical discussion
The Enlightenment period and the ideas that defined it as well as modern implications
I learned a lot of intellectual history from 1789 to 1848. I also had the opportunity to write a research paper on a topic of my choosing.
I learned about different movements in the Age of Revolutions. I learned a lot about how to participate in a group discussion, as well as how to read large quantities of written material thoroughly.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
The strength of this course is the essay.  Being able to choose your own topic is really nice and Professor Schettini is really knowledgeable about the course in general. He is very helpful when you go to office hours and can recommend a lot of good places to look for sources. Also, the structure of the class forces you to work on your essay over the whole semester, so you don't have to scramble during reading week. 
The weakness is the class discussion. Because everyone comes from a different level of prior knowledge, having a big discussion is really hard. I think Professor Schettini needs to assign more secondary sources because it would be helpful to have some knowledge about the the importance of these documents. It also might be helpful to have to do a reading response each week to make sure everyone is engaged with the sources.
The course material is genuinely interesting, but engagement across the class was low. Perhaps the Professor could be a bit more inspired in convincing everyone to do the readings and contribute.

It's just hard to focus with such a long class block. The readings and discussions, as well as a final project were strengths. Professor Schettini's feedback is amazing and unlike any other feedback I've gotten at Yale.
I wish it were shorter and met twice a week because it was hard to stay focused the entire time.
Strengths: great professor, interesting content, low workload. Weakness: sometimes seminar moved a bit slowly, and could focus on more historical background.

The course itself is very well designed, with each week focusing on a different topic. I loved how the discussions would diverge from specific questions about the readings to larger questions about broad concepts.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I wouldn't recommend this course unless you want to learn more about the Age of Revolutions and have some background knowledge of the time period. I came in with almost none, and week to week, this course was hard to get through and I don't think I got as much out of it as someone who would have had more background knowledge.
Absolutely! It's so interesting and a much better way to learn about important authors than big lecture halls.
I really enjoyed Glauco's teacher and mentorship. He was always ready to help and go above and beyond.
Yes, very good seminar. Light workload, interesting content, great professor, and chance to research topic of your choice related to the intellectual history of this era.
Yes, this class was overall great.
